repnme.cdata!:
Croatia - Enterprise and Financial Sector
            Adjustment Loan, Enterprise and Financial Sector Technical
            Assistance, and Capital Markets Development Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The Enterprise And Financial Sector
            Adjustment Loan Project (EFSAL) is rated moderately
            unsatisfactory; its sustainability is likely; institutional
            development impact is modest; and Bank and Borrower
            performance both unsatisfactory. The project outcome of the
            Enterprise And Financial Sector Technical Assistance Project
            (TAL) is moderately satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is modest; Bank performance
            is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is unsatisfactory.
            For the Capital Markets Development Project (CMDP), outcome
            is rated moderately unsatisfactory; sustainability is
            unlikely; institutional development impact is modest; and
            both Bank and Borrower performance are unsatisfactory.
            Lessons of general applicability include the following: 1)
            Without complementary measures for facilitating entry and
            exit, maintaining hard budgetary constraints, and imposing
            corporate managerial accountability, privatization is
            unlikely to produce significant growth or productivity
            benefits. 2) Troubled banks should be liquidated or
            privatized quickly, and their lending strictly controlled
            while in that process. 3) The experience with the EFSAL
            suggests that, although additional delays may be incurred
            and costs increased, on balance long-run development
            benefits are likely to be enhanced by canceling projects
            with major design flaws and addressing the reform needs with
            a superior instrument. 4) Development of domestic capital
            markets makes little sense, until basic issues for private
            sector development, such as privatization and financial
            stabilization, have been resolved.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project rating is satisfactory,
            having achieved its main objectives, in developing capital
            markets institutional infrastructure, required for a market
            economy. It facilitated the economic transformation in
            Croatia, and built the necessary operational, and regulatory
            capacity to meet growing investment requirements in the
            private sector. Sustainability however, differs among some
            components: the Public Awareness component, will require
            further financing to target the professional capital market
            community; the Policy Framework component, led to the
            creation of the Croatian Securities and Exchange Commission,
            which achieved international recognition. Yet, additional
            technical assistance financing needs to be provided; and,
            the Securities Depositary Agency, created under the
            Infrastructure component, is subject to an uncertain
            sustainability. The key lessons focus on: 1) the expertise
            of project management, which was developed within the
            Project's Management Unit, was a key element, since its
            core group of trained staff, now contributes to the work of
            the Ministry of Finance; 2) the strong counterpart
            commitment, and project ownership, reinforced by outside
            expertise, proved decisive, and diligent in achieving
            success; 3) the adequate project design defined simple
            components, complementary to the policy reform program; and,
            4) while political risks were high, evidence proves the
            success of Croatia's capital markets.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Capital Markets
            Development Project are to strengthen key government areas,
            including: (a) the regulatory and policy framework of the
            capital markets; (b) the infrastructure to support
            securities transactions; and (c) the public's
            understanding of the capital markets and their roles as
            shareholders of privatized firms. The project consists of
            three components. The policy support component supports
            development of a legal and regulatory framework. The
            infrastructure development component provides technical
            assistance, equipment and facilities investments to
            establish and strengthen the securities depository,
            registry, clearing and settlement facilities. Finally, the
            public awareness component provides technical assistance to
            devise, develop and execute a mass media public awareness
            campaign. The campaign seeks to improve the general
            public's understanding of the capital markets and of
            their role and rights as participants.
